title: 105_hr1321
content: The "Expedited Rescissions Act of 1997" allows for quick consideration of proposed rescissions under the Congressional Budget and Impoundment Control Act of 1974. The "Expedited Rescissions Act of 1997" allows the President to propose rescinding budget authority provided in an appropriation Act by transmitting a special message to Congress within 3 days of the Act's enactment. The proposed rescission can only be done once and must clearly identify the amount of budget authority to be rescinded. The President can propose rescinding budget authority by sending a special message to Congress within 3 days of an appropriation Act's enactment. The message must specify the amount to be rescinded and follow expedited consideration procedures. The House of Representatives must introduce a draft bill accompanying a special message from the President within three legislative days. If not introduced, any Member of the House can introduce the bill. The bill will be referred to the Committee on Appropriations and must be reported without substantive revision by the seventh legislative day. The Committee on Appropriations must report the bill within seven legislative days, or it will be automatically discharged. A vote on final passage must be taken in the House of Representatives within the 10th legislative day. If passed, the bill will be transmitted to the Senate within one calendar day. Debate in the House of Representatives on a bill under this section shall not exceed 4 hours, divided equally between those favoring and opposing the bill. Motion to limit debate or reconsider the vote is not debatable. No recommitting or reconsidering the vote on the bill. The Rules of the House of Representatives apply to bill procedures without debate. A bill sent to the Senate goes to the Committee on Appropriations, which must report it within seven legislative days. If not reported, the committee is discharged, and the bill is placed on the calendar. The Senate must vote on the bill within the 10th legislative day after receiving it. The Senate has specific rules for considering bills, including privileged motions and limited debate time. The Senate has rules for considering bills, including limited debate time and restrictions on amendments and divisions. Amendments to bills under this section are not allowed in the House of Representatives or the Senate. Privileged motions to further limit debate on a bill are not debatable, and motions to recommit a bill are not in order. In the House of Representatives and the Senate, restrictions are in place for dividing questions and suspending subsections. Budget authority proposed for rescission must be made available for obligation after specific conditions are met. The bill allows for rescissions to be made in accordance with the President's special message. Definitions for "appropriation Act" and "legislative day" are provided. Rulemaking powers under Section 904 of the Act are amended, and conforming amendments are made to Section 1011. Section 1011 of the Act is amended to update paragraph numbers, while Section 1015 is also amended to reflect changes in subsections and references. Section 1016 of the Act is amended to update paragraph numbers and references, including the insertion of new subparagraphs and the redesignation of existing ones. The table of sections for subpart B of title X of the Act is amended to redesignate items relating to sections 1013 through 1017 as items relating to sections 1014 through 1018, and to insert a new item after section 1012. "Sec. 1013. Expedited consideration of certain proposed rescissions." Section 1013 of the Congressional Budget and Impoundment Control Act of 1974 applies to budget authority provided by appropriation Acts enacted during the One Hundred Fifth Congress and thereafter. The President may propose rescinding budget authority within 3 days of a new Congress if the previous Congress did not consider the proposed rescissions before adjourning. The President may propose rescinding budget authority within 3 days of a new Congress if the previous Congress did not consider the proposed rescissions before adjourning. A draft bill must accompany a special message for rescissions, to be introduced in the House of Representatives within a specified timeframe. The House and Senate will then proceed to consider the bill as outlined in section 1013.
